author: Daniel Samsami
title: Storage of medical metadata
description: Medical documentation should be safe and cost-efficient. Outdated systems makes the process ineffective, non-standardized and expensive.

assessments.note: There is a need to have a blockchain verified storage mechanism for medical data. A multiprong approach to solve this problem will lead to development of at least one good solution. The proposal sets an achievable target and is likely to add value to the use of Metadata.

The proposal gives an interesting approach to the usage of metadata. The uploaded presentation of the app is nice and show's the importance of efficient medical documentation. However it is not fully disclosed how the data is planned to be utilized in addition to that, i.e. what the purpose of transferring it to blockchain is. You should reflect on that ahead of your proposal to present a good solution there. Keep in mind that you are asking 50000 Dollars of funds, it would be good to know what the exact purpose and potential of this could be other than "using it for further applications".

The problem and solution description is reasonable and directly related to the challenge.

The proposal describes how it will use metadata to store data about patients, but the lack of metrics, goals or KPIs makes it difficult to measure the impact on the challenge.

I recommend establishing these items so that we can assess the impact for Cardano's blockchain.

The proposal's intention to store medical information on-chain coincides with the challenge's immutable recording of event data such as transaction metadata. However, the proposal is not specific about how the solution will implement the privacy and confidentiality that are critical for medical data, especially in countries with rigorous privacy regulations. It is not clear what that project's goals are in distinction against the long-term aspirations presented in the proposal. The proposal also does not reference medical-data standards or clarify whether the project would develop its own standards.

Whilst the proposers have experience that would allow a project like this to be developed, with both domain and technical expertise, the plan is lacking in details on what will be produced. What interfaces will be produces for data entry and querying. How will patient consent be handled. Will they be enabling differential privacy on qureying?
The proposers claim adequate experience. A combination of medical practitioners and a developer is ideal for the settings.

While, after researching the proposers, it seems reasonable to say they are competent in their fields, the plan is not very detailed yet, which makes this seem rather an early stage project where some potential has been detected but proper goals and milestones have not been set yet. Considering you are asking the entire amount of funding for the challenge and other projects that are far more modest budget wise have much more concrete plans, this is not sufficient. By the way I would not call the budget you are asking for a "minimal salary". What you are asking for amounts to about the average salary in sweden, not a minimal salary. (I know it is a pretty low salary for your job segments, but just consider that the salaries in sweden and skandinavia in general are some of the highest in the world and yet it's possible to live on a lot less there). So considering the limited funding from Catalyst can go into a lot of very important projects where some of them have positive impacts on a lot of different fields, you should maybe consider accepting a lower salary if you are passionate about forwarding this project.

The team is already working on the development of systems to automate and standardize medical records through metadata, and has won awards for ideas and prototypes. No links or information have been described to attest to the qualifications and work cited in the proposal, which is essential for us to confirm the team's aptitude to develop the project.

There is no detailed implementation plan. The proposal describes that the team will spend most of the funds on salaries for 6 to 8 months, but this needs to be more detailed so that we can assess the feasibility of the proposal.

In addition to wages, what costs will there be? What are the project's deliverables? We need to understand what will be delivered in relation to the requested budget to judge the feasibility.

The project team has the right combination of medical and software experience to successfully pursue this work. The proposal presents a staged plan with vaguely defined intermediate milestones that are not tied to a timeline or a detailed list of constituent activities. In general, a lot more technical justification should be included for a proposal of this size.

The proposal requires a lot more detail. What exactly is being produces on both front and backend systems. How is this connecting to the real world (doctors, patients, researchers, regulators). How are they ensuring privacy and enabling changes in consent to view data etc.

The proposal is from a two-member team with a plan to acquire developers along the way. It is a feasible plan, there is a scope for improvement by developing a detailed plan with deliverables in phases.

Unfortunately, the information about the project is very vague. While it points out some potential that can be examined further, it clearly still NEEDS some more examining and more concrete ideas ahead of applying for funding.

The only information described to audit the proposal was a delivery period between 6 to 8 months and that part of the budget will be used for the team's salary during this period.

There is no reasonable roadmap, there are no details on budget allocation, there are no metrics, no KPIs, no deliverables.

This information is important so that we can judge the auditability of the proposal, so I recommend the inclusion of these items and that the team follow the Catalyst documentation as a reference to prepare the proposal.

The specific outcomes, timeline, and stages of the project are not defined in enough detail for confident auditing of intermediate progress on the project. The 6-8 month final goal is not defined concretely enough to quantify whether specific capabilities have been successfully achieved.

solution: Storage of medical data on blockchain safely and standardized which allows for further implementations and increases overall patient safety.
experience: Daniel is a medical doctor with field knowledge and relevant clinical experience. Alex is a full stack developer and blockchain enthusiast.
